```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

```
```{r load data}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(reshape2)
load('house_loaded.RData')
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:
```{r Corrplot}
num_cols <- sapply(house_train, is.numeric)
num_house_train=house_train[,num_cols]
num_house_train
source('corplot.R')
corplot(num_house_train)

```


High Correlations
Garage Cars
```{r Explore SalePrice vs OverallQual}
colSums(is.na(house_train)) * 100 / nrow(house_train)
plot(house_train$OverallQual,house_train$SalePrice)
ggplot(house_train, aes(x=OverallQual,y=log(SalePrice)))+geom_violin()+geom_boxplot(width=.1)
house_train%>%group_by(OverallQual)%>%summarise(sd(SalePrice),min(SalePrice),max(SalePrice),mean(SalePrice))


summary(house_train)
```

## MS Zoning

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
house_train$MSZoning=(house_train$MSZoning=='RM')

```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
